element.name: Balrothery Castle by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

long-description.p: Balrothery was an administrative centre for the Norman's, which accounts for its present name, Baile na Ridire (Town of the Knights). The knights of Fingal used to attend meetings in Balrothery to discuss land and Church disputes. Balrothery Village became the centre of the great Barony of Balrothery, which covered most of North Fingal. .

In the mid 18th Century, Balrothery had a population of over 4,500 people and boasted a chair factory, two breweries and two biscuit factories. The biscuits from these factories were ships biscuits, and were greatly favoured by the British Navy as they stayed crisp and fresh for a very long period of time. Nelson demanded Balrothery biscuits for his ships.

On the western side of the Belfast Road through Balrothery, there is a large Celtic cross erected over a mass grave of the unfortunate paupers who perished in the workhouse which was situated along the Balrothery "straight" until recent times.
The cache is a micro hidden in the grounds of the church and tower
Please replace the cache carefully to avoid muggles

ul.li:
2010-06-13T19:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
Found this cache by accident as we were driving home from Ardgillan. The little marker apeared on the Sat Nav & sure we had to stop. Found easily enough. TFTC Toffee Man #366

2010-06-13T19:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
Break in the rain on the way home soaked from Ardgillan. Found it very easily, but did feel slightly disrespectful. A family of ants have moved into cache container and I think they are eating the log, which is disintegrating. TFTC #364

2010-05-03T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by Geo Chief
After a long search there was nothing to find.
Greetings Geo Chief

2010-03-21T19:00:00Z : Found it by Petr Skacha
Found it on the third visit, it is easier after gardener done his job. Take your own pencil, no one there.

2010-02-07T20:00:00Z : Found it by Zoe andDaddy
Found while out for a full day caching with Mr Frezeluberz. 49/51
Nice spot for a cache found this on in the dark on our way home.
Thanks

wpt.name: GCYD89
wpt.desc: Balrothery Castle by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Balrothery Castle
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Balrothery was an administrative centre for the Norman's, which accounts for its present name, Baile na Ridire (Town of the Knights). The knights of Fingal used to attend meetings in Balrothery to discuss land and Church disputes. Balrothery Village became the centre of the great Barony of Balrothery, which covered most of North Fingal. .

In the mid 18th Century, Balrothery had a population of over 4,500 people and boasted a chair factory, two breweries and two biscuit factories. The biscuits from these factories were ships biscuits, and were greatly favoured by the British Navy as they stayed crisp and fresh for a very long period of time. Nelson demanded Balrothery biscuits for his ships.

On the western side of the Belfast Road through Balrothery, there is a large Celtic cross erected over a mass grave of the unfortunate paupers who perished in the workhouse which was situated along the Balrothery "straight" until recent times.

The Cache

The cache is a micro hidden in the grounds of the church and tower

Please replace the cache carefully to avoid muggles



The Windsockers

Break in the rain on the way home soaked from Ardgillan. Found it very easily, but did feel slightly disrespectful. A family of ants have moved into cache container and I think they are eating the log, which is disintegrating. TFTC #364

After a long search there was nothing to find.
Greetings Geo Chief
